practice_problems.hint: Professional design does not guarantee accuracy — always evaluate content, authority, and evidence.

practice_problems.question: If a source has no author, no citations, and is trying to sell you something, it is likely:
options: Not a reliable source for research

practice_problems.question: Sources that analyze or interpret primary sources are called ___ sources.

content.explanation: MLA (Modern Language Association) format is the standard citation style for English and humanities classes. Its purpose is to give proper credit to sources, allow readers to find your sources, and provide a consistent format for academic writing. Key MLA formatting rules: use 12-point Times New Roman font, double-space the entire document, set one-inch margins on all sides, include a header with your last name and page number in the upper right corner, and create a heading on the first page with your name, instructor's name, course, and date. In-text citations include the author's last name and page number in parentheses: (Smith 42). If you mention the author's name in the sentence, only include the page number: Smith argues that '...' (42). The Works Cited page lists all sources alphabetically by the author's last name. A basic book entry: Last, First. Title of Book. Publisher, Year. A basic website entry: Author. 'Article Title.' Website Name, Date, URL. MLA 9th edition uses a core elements system: Author, Title of Source, Title of Container, Contributors, Version, Number, Publisher, Date, Location.

examples.problem: Format an in-text citation for page 87 of a book by John Smith.
examples.answer: (Smith 87) at the end of the sentence, or: Smith argues that '...' (87) if you name the author in the sentence.
examples.explanation: The period goes after the parenthetical citation, not before it.

examples.problem: Create a Works Cited entry for the novel 'To Kill a Mockingbird' by Harper Lee, published by Grand Central Publishing in 2010.
examples.answer: Lee, Harper. To Kill a Mockingbird. Grand Central Publishing, 2010.
examples.explanation: Author's last name first, then first name. Book title in italics. Publisher, then year.

examples.problem: What are the basic page formatting rules for MLA?
examples.answer: 12-point Times New Roman, double-spaced, one-inch margins, last name and page number header in upper right, and a heading with student name, instructor, course, and date on the first page.
examples.explanation: Consistent formatting makes academic papers look professional and readable.

content.real_world: While MLA is specific to academic writing, the principle of citing sources applies everywhere — in journalism, business, and law. Understanding a citation system teaches you to track and attribute information rigorously.

content.explanation: Plagiarism is presenting someone else's ideas, words, or work as your own without proper attribution. It is a serious academic and ethical violation that can result in failing grades, suspension, or expulsion. Plagiarism includes: copying text word-for-word without quotation marks and citation (even a single sentence), paraphrasing someone's ideas without citation, submitting someone else's work as your own, self-plagiarism (resubmitting your own previous work without permission), and patchwriting (rearranging a source's sentence structure while keeping the ideas and many of the words). To avoid plagiarism: take careful notes while researching, clearly distinguishing your ideas from source material. Use quotation marks for any exact language from a source. Cite all paraphrases and summaries. When in doubt, cite. Develop your own analytical voice — your essay should be primarily your own thinking, supported by evidence from sources, not a collection of other people's ideas stitched together. Use sources to support your argument, not replace it.

examples.problem: Is this plagiarism? You read that 'social media increases anxiety in teenagers' and write in your essay 'social media increases anxiety in teens' without citing the source.
examples.answer: Yes, this is plagiarism — it is patchwriting. You changed one word ('teenagers' to 'teens') but the idea and most of the language are from the source. You must cite it.
examples.explanation: Changing a few words does not make the idea yours. If the idea came from a source, cite it.

examples.problem: How do you properly paraphrase?
examples.answer: Read the source, put it away, write the idea in your own words and sentence structure, then cite the source. Compare your version to the original to ensure you have not copied language. 'According to Johnson, adolescent anxiety has risen alongside social media usage (42).'
examples.explanation: Good paraphrasing means genuinely restating the idea in your own voice, not just swapping synonyms.

examples.problem: What is self-plagiarism?
examples.answer: Submitting work you previously completed for another class or assignment without the instructor's permission. Even though you wrote it, resubmitting it misrepresents it as new work.
examples.explanation: Always ask your instructor if you want to build on or reuse previous work.

content.real_world: Plagiarism has real-world consequences beyond school. Journalists lose careers over it. Politicians face scandals. Researchers are discredited. Building a habit of honest attribution now serves you for life.

practice_problems.question: Patchwriting is:
options: Rewriting a source's ideas with only minor word changes, without citation

practice_problems.question: Presenting someone else's ideas or words as your own without proper attribution is called ___.
To properly paraphrase, you should:
options: Change two or three words and keep the rest

practice_problems.hint: Commonly known facts do not require citation, but when in doubt, cite.

options: Submitting your own previous work as new work without permission

content.explanation: Digital literacy is the ability to critically evaluate, create, and communicate with digital media. In a world where information spreads instantly and anyone can publish content, digital literacy is as essential as traditional reading literacy. Key skills include: identifying misinformation (false information spread unintentionally) and disinformation (false information spread deliberately to deceive). Check claims by verifying them through multiple reputable sources. Practice lateral reading — instead of evaluating a source by reading it closely, open new tabs to learn about the source, the author, and their claims from independent sources. Recognize common manipulation techniques: emotional headlines designed to provoke clicks (clickbait), images taken out of context, cherry-picked statistics, false equivalence (presenting fringe opinions as equal to expert consensus), and bot-generated content. Understand that algorithms curate your information diet, creating filter bubbles and echo chambers that reinforce existing beliefs. Seek out diverse perspectives deliberately. When sharing information online, verify before you share — you become part of the information chain.

examples.problem: What is the difference between misinformation and disinformation?
examples.answer: Misinformation is false information shared by people who believe it is true. Disinformation is false information deliberately created and spread to deceive. The intent differs — one is a mistake, the other is manipulation.
examples.explanation: Both are harmful, but disinformation is more insidious because it is designed to exploit cognitive biases.

examples.problem: What is lateral reading?
examples.answer: Instead of evaluating a source by reading it deeply, you open new tabs to check what independent sources say about the publisher, author, and claims. Professional fact-checkers use this strategy — they leave the site to verify it.
examples.explanation: Reading a website's 'About Us' page tells you what they want you to think. Lateral reading tells you what others say about them.

examples.problem: How do filter bubbles affect your understanding of issues?
examples.answer: Algorithms show you content similar to what you have already engaged with, creating an echo chamber where you mostly encounter perspectives that confirm your existing beliefs. This can make you overconfident in your views and unaware of legitimate opposing arguments.
examples.explanation: Deliberately seeking out diverse, reputable sources counters this effect.

content.real_world: Digital literacy is arguably the most important civic skill of the 21st century. Every day you encounter claims, arguments, and content that require critical evaluation. Your ability to distinguish reliable from unreliable information shapes your decisions as a citizen, consumer, and community member.
